tossups.question: One book with this concept in its title describes this concept as “not a biologically driven complex” and begins with the observation that “no man sees the world through pristine eyes.” The Sony Walkman is used as a lens to understand this concept in a book about “Doing” studies of it by Paul Du Gay. Historical particularism rejects the school of thought that posits the “evolution” of this concept and instead casts this concept as a product of its history. One work calls this concept “personality (*) writ large” and contrasts the Apollonian and Dionysian types of them. This term names a branch of anthropology that refrains from judging one of these concepts by the standards of another, known as its namesake relativism. Ruth Benedict wrote about its “Patterns.” For 10 points, name this term that denotes the set of beliefs, customs, norms, and ways of life that characterize a particular society.
tossups.answer: culture [or cultural relativism; accept Patterns of Culture]

tossups.question: Dr. Pedro Ara embalmed this person’s body, which was secretly buried in Milan after the “Liberating Revolution.” This person wrote an autobiography called “The Reason for My Life.” This person created a namesake foundation after being snubbed by the Sociedad de Beneficencia. Huge crowds tried to convince this politician to run for Vice President in the Cabildo Abierto rally. This person was accused of hiding Nazi treasures in Switzerland during a trip where this person also met Pius XII, which was dubbed a (*) ”Rainbow Tour” of Europe. This actress played Queen Elizabeth on a radio show called The Great Women of History and coined the name for her husband’s shirtless supporters, the descamisados. Name this First Lady of Argentina and second wife of Juan, who, for 10 points, was played by Madonna in a 1996 film adapted from a musical.
tossups.answer: Maria Eva Peron [Evita Peron; or Eva Duarte; prompt on partial answer]

tossups.question: In a novel by this author, switchboard operator Fred Bogner leaves his wife Kate with three children but meets her occasionally for one-night stands in cheap hotels. In another work by this author, art historian Fritz Tolm is elected as the head of the mysterious “Association” and consequently surrounded by security forces. This author of And Never Said a Word and The Safety Net wrote about a bellboy referred to as a (*) “lamb” in a novel that ends with a family cutting a building-shaped cake. This author of “rubble literature” wrote about a man whose Catholic lover Marie leaves him, leading him to sadly play guitar in a train station. This author wrote about Hans Schnier in The Clown, as well as wri a novel in which Robert blows up St. Anthony’s Abbey, which his grandfather Heinrich Faehmel designed. For 10 points, name this author of Billiards at Half-Past Nine.
tossups.answer: Heinrich Theodor Boll

tossups.question: As a child, this figure knew that the “B” “S” and “M” sounds in a certain word stood for the glory, radiance, and sovereignty, respectively. This figure’s mother took a vow of silence at the time of this figure’s birth, so he spoke up from the cradle in order to identify himself. This figure is the most-mentioned person in the Qur’an. This figure’s prayers will cause God to kill some evil people with deadly parasitic worms. The breath of this person will kill the followers of the (*) Masih ad-Dajjal (ma-see ad dej-jaal), and this figure will kill that Prince of Lies with a spear as he fights on the side of the Mahdi. When this figure was being born, Allah made a spring come forth under his mother’s feet and provided her with dates. For 10 points, name this penultimate prophet of Islam, who is the son of Maryam but not Allah.
tossups.answer: ‘Isa [or Jesus]

tossups.question: Breakdown of this tissue is a feared side effect of the antibiotic daptomycin. It’s not the skin, but a heliotrope rash, the shawl sign, and Gottron’s papules are symptoms of a disease in which this tissue becomes inflamed. Satellite cells serve as quiescent stem cells in this tissue. Coenzyme Q10 supplements are used to prevent drugs like pravastatin from breaking down this tissue, a process called (*) rhabdomyolysis. Myf5, MRF4, and MyoD are a series of basic helix-loop-helix transcription factors needed for differentiation of this tissue. The functional unit of this tissue is bounded by two Z lines, and contains thick filaments in the A band and thin filaments in the I band; that functional unit is the sarcomere, and contains actin and myosin. For 10 points, name this tissue that comes in cardiac, smooth, and skeletal varieties.
tossups.answer: skeletal muscle

tossups.question: Description acceptable. A man says “I don’t think two people could have been happier than we’ve been” before doing this action to avoid a party celebrating him winning the Carrouthers Prize in The Hours. That character was based on a man who does this action to avoid “human nature,” personified by the approaching Dr. Holmes. The headline of an anti-government pamphlet inspires a character to do this after being locked in a room by F. Alexander and made ill by (*) classical music due to the Ludovico Technique. Alex is rehabilitated at the end of A Clockwork Orange after performing this act, which Septimus Smith does to kill himself in Mrs. Dalloway. For 10 points, a flip-book animation at the end of Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close shows a man doing what action in reverse, in reference to people who performed it to escape the towers on 9/11?
tossups.answer: defenestration [prompt on “falling”; accept reasonable equivalents like “jumping out of a window” or “being thrown out of a window”; prompt on “suicide”]

tossups.question: A disheveled woman carrying her drunken husband on her back refuses this historical figure’s assistance in Thomas Nast’s cartoon “GET THEE BEHIND ME SATAN.” After being introduced to spiritualist theology by Colonel James Blood, this person found work in New York City conducting seances for Cornelius Vanderbilt. Anthony Comstock began his anti-obscenity campaign after this person published a salacious article about Elizabeth Tilton’s affair with Henry Ward Beecher. With Tennessee Claflin, this advocate of (*) “free love” ran a namesake weekly newspaper and operated the first female-owned brokerage firm on Wall Street. This woman selected Frederick Douglas as her running mate while running as the Equal Rights Party candidate in 1872. For 10 points, name this first woman to run for president.
tossups.answer: Victoria Claflin Woodhull [or Victoria California Claflin before “Claflin” is mentioned; Victoria Woodhull Martin]

tossups.question: Mass spectrometry of these compounds can use the 2,5-DHB MALDI matrix, and these compounds are usually permethylated before MS. Alcian blue staining is used when conducting electrophoresis on these compounds. High-performance anion exchange coupled with pulsed amperometric detection is used to separate these compounds, which can be liberated using PNGase F. A mixture of carbonate, citrate, and copper (II) sulfate is used to detect these compounds with a free aldehyde on the end; that mixture is called (*) Benedict’s reagent and detects reducing types of these. Haworth and Fischer projections are commonly used to show their stereochemistry, and they commonly have carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in approximately a 1 to 2 to 1 ratio. For 10 points, name these macromolecules that include glucose.
tossups.answer: sugars [or saccharides, or monosaccharides, or disaccharides, or oligosaccharides, or polysaccharides; accept glycoproteins or proteoglycans]

tossups.question: This figure warns his killer that he will be drowned if he is careless in crossing the sea and tells him about the island of Oskapt; that killer refuses to tell this figure his name or family. This figure wears the Helmet of Terror, owns the swords Ridill and Hrotti, and can breathe poison. His most notable possession was used to cover the dead body of his brother. To kill this figure, a hero was advised to (*) dig more trenches so he wouldn’t drown in this figure’s blood; the blood running over him made him invulnerable instead and gave him the ability to understand birds. He was killed by the sword Gram, which was made by this creature’s brother. This creature killed his father Hreidmar to get the gold of Andvari. For 10 points, name this brother of Otter and Regin, a dragon who was killed by Sigurd in the Volsung saga.
tossups.answer: Fafnir

tossups.question: Toru Takemitsu was inspired to compose Quatrain II as a homage to this work when the composer of this work played an excerpt for him on piano. The Tashi Group is probably best known for recording this piece for RCA label. The first movement of this piece notably uses ragavardhana rhythm and sees the cello play a five-note ostinato of C-E-D-F-sharp-B-flat throughout the entire movement. Another movement is based on (*) the sixth mode of limited transposition, a practice that the composer outlined in his treatise The Technique of My Musical Language. A violin solo begins the final movement of this piece entitled “Praise to the Immortality of Jesus,” while the movement “Abyss of Birds” features a slow clarinet solo. For 10 points, name this piece composed during the composer’s time in a German POW camp, a work by Olivier Messiaen.
tossups.answer: Quartet for the End of Time [or Quatuor pour la fin du temps]

tossups.question: One of this man’s sculptures unusually contains a cable, which a father is using to fasten wings onto his son. Karl Fernow criticized this man’s works for having no primary point from which they could be viewed, because some were intended to be placed on rotating pedestals. One work by this man shows three women with braided hair holding a scarf and leaning their heads together in a circle. Another sculpture by this artist of The Three Graces aroused controversy due to its portrayal of a (*) high-ranking woman reclining nude to the waist on a couch. A woman arches her neck backwards and encircles her arms around her winged lover standing above her in another of his works, typical of his Greek-inspired style. For 10 points, name this neoclassical Italian sculptor of Psyche Revived by Cupid’s Kiss who depicted Napoleon’s sister Pauline Borghese as Venus Victrix.
tossups.answer: Antonio Canova

tossups.question: A poet from this country praised a religious friend who “rest[s] on a wedge of cloud and mist.” That man claims “Constant friends, although we wander, we’ll meet again in the Milky Way.” Eliot Weinberger and Octavio Paz wrote about “Nineteen Ways of Looking At” a poet from this country, contrasting translations by Kenneth Rexroth and Gary Snyder which mention a “far off voice” among “green moss” and a “mountain wilderness.” A poem from this country evokes the sound of (*) wheels rumbling and horses whinnying as conscripts pass by, and another work from this country begins “I take my wine jug out among the flowers.” The authors of “The Song of the Wagons,” “The River Captain’s Wife,” and “Drinking Alone By Moonlight” come from this country. For 10 points, name this country whose poets include Wang Wei, Tu Fu, and Li Po.
tossups.answer: People’s Republic of China [or Zhongguo]

tossups.question: One pioneer in this industry used the symbol of a dolphin entwined around an anchor to represent the phrase “festina lente.” A book about this industry takes a mosaic approach and analyzes the “darker purpose” of the subdivision of King Lear’s kingdom. Johann Fust helped finance an innovation in it before bringing a lawsuit for allegedly unpaid loans. More portable products in this industry were created by the Venetian Aldus Manutius. This industry’s (*) “capitalism” was integral to the creation of nations through formation of “Imagined Communities” according to Benedict Anderson. Only 49 copies of a 42-line object created by this industry survive. This industry became more prominent after cast metal replaced woodblocks. For 10 points, name this industry that took off after the invention of moveable type by Johannes Gutenberg.
tossups.answer: printing [accept obvious equivalents, like book-making; (the second clue is from Marshall McLuhan’s The Gutenberg Galaxy)]

tossups.question: This property is the infinitesimal holonomy around a closed loop according to the Ambrose-Singer theorem. The asymptotic behavior of one quantity encoding this property is given by the big-O of the affine parameter to the negative fifth by the peeling theorem. One quantity encoding this property is decomposed into scalar, semi-traceless, and traceless components by the Kulkarni-Nomizu product. One half times the metric tensor times the scalar version of this quantity appears in one term of the (*) Einstein field equation. One quantity used to define it can be expressed entirely in terms of the Christoffel symbols and their first derivatives. The Weyl tensor, the Ricci tensor, and the Riemann tensor all describe this property, which is zero for Euclidean geometry and negative for hyperbolic geometry. For 10 points, name this quantity which produces gravity according to the theory of relativity, the deviation from flatness.
tossups.answer: curvature

tossups.question: One person with this name created a namesake type of literary imitation that supplanted Aristotle’s mimesis among Romans like Quintilian. That person wrote a history called Roman Antiquities and was from Halicarnassus. A person with this name led the losing Ionians in the Battle of Lade and was from Phocaea. A person with this name expelled the philosopher Dion under the advice of Plato and was besieged in a citadel on Ortygia by Timoleon. That ruler supposedly had the literal Sword of Damocles hanging over his head, which didn’t improve his rule much, and along with an “Elder” father, was a tyrant of (*) Syracuse. Two days of a festival to a god of this name were devoted to dithyrambs. Each participant in that festival created a work featuring Satyrs in the chorus. For 10 points, name this god to whom Athens dedicated its yearly festival of plays.
tossups.answer: Dionysius [or Great Dionysia; City Dionysia]

tossups.question: A participant in one of these events accused a rival of doing sketchy things in the bathroom, dubbed “Toiletgate,” and those two people still refuse to shake hands with each other. Rival ones of these events were held from 1993 to 2005 by the PCA, including one in 1995 in the World Trade Center. These are the most important of the events that can reach a sudden death “Armageddon” round. Wilhelm (*) Steinitz is generally considered the first winner of these events. One of these events almost did not happen until Jim Slater doubled the prize fund and Henry Kissinger called one participant. That one of these events in Reykjavik in 1972 was called the “Match of the Century” and dethroned Boris Spassky, ending 24 years of Soviet domination. For 10 points, name these events officiated by FIDE, the most recent of which was won by Magnus Carlsen.
tossups.answer: World Chess Championship [prompt on “Chess tournament” or “chess game;” do not accept the Chess Championship of any country or region other than “World”]

tossups.question: A type of rock containing a high yttrium to strontium ratio known as adakite can form in the flat-slab type of these regions. A force affecting these regions contains a term equal to 4.2 times acceleration due to gravity and is known as slab pull. The emplacement of ophiolites is a result of the formation of back-arc basins in these regions. Seismic activity in these regions occurs in (*) Wadati-Benioff zones, where megathrust earthquakes can occur due to significant accumulation of stress. A large example of these regions forms the boundary between the North American and Juan de Fuca plates and is the Cascadian one of these regions. For 10 points, name these convergent plate boundaries where one plate sinks under another.
tossups.answer: subduction zones [prompt on “plate boundaries” or “convergent boundaries” until read]

tossups.question: A poem by this author addresses a “gentle-hearted” friend who “hast pined / and hunger’d after Nature, many a year.” In another poem, this author exclaims “But thou, my babe! shalt wander like a breeze” in a poem by this author describes a separation from “Friends, whom I never more may meet again” and imagines those friends journeying among the Quantocks, saying “Well, they are gone, and here must I (*) remain.” This author, who wrote about being “imprisoned” in a lime-tree bower during a visit with Charles Lamb, described “silent icicles / Quietly shining to the quiet moon,” in a poem addressed to his infant son Hartley, one of his “conversation poems.” An opium dream inspired this poet to write about “caverns measureless to man” and “stately pleasure-dome” in Xanadu. For 10 points, name this author of “Frost at Midnight” and “Kubla Khan.”
tossups.answer: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

tossups.question: A work named for this concept ends with Nature ordering mankind to “remove this disgusting debris” and remain peacefully within an “indestructible mansion.” Another work opposing a “duty” against this policy emphasizes the “natural light” of reason. Pierre Bayle’s Commentaire Philosophique defends this practice and attacks Augustine’s interpretation of a parable from Luke 14. A treatise about this policy opens with a “brief account of the death of” a man accused of (*) murdering his son, Jean Calas, and excoriates the magistrates of Toulouse. An influential argument that the government is responsible for “civil interests,” not “the care of the soul,” appears in John Locke’s A Letter Concerning this policy. For 10 points, name this religious policy that forbids religious persecution but is more limited than religious freedom.
tossups.answer: religious tolerance [accept word forms like toleration; prompt on “separation of church and state”; prompt on “freedom of religion” before mention]

tossups.question: One of this artist’s last-known paintings is contested because of its use of bright reds and blues, and it depicts a baby Christ playing with Mary’s rosary. Michael Levey argued that one of this artist’s works is a self-portrait, challenging the conventional view that it adheres to Cesare Ripa’s Iconologia. In that work, the title figure has dishevelled black hair and wears a golden chain. In one work by this artist of Self-Portrait of the Allegory of Painting, two (*) old men creepily lean over a wall in an effort to blackmail a naked girl who angrily leans away from them. In this artist’s most famous work, a man whose appearance is supposedly based on the artist’s rapist clutches the neck of a servant in red as the title character beheads him, spurting blood everywhere. For 10 points, name this non-Caravaggio artist of Susanna and the Elders and Judith Slaying Holofernes.
tossups.answer: Artemisia Gentileschi Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the post-World War II world order. For 10 points each:
answers: Bretton Woods conference [or Bretton Woods system]
parts: This conference held in New Hampshire in July, 1944 laid the foundation for the World Bank and the IMF. This conference also established a namesake system of fixed exchange rates ended by the Nixon Shock.

John Ruggie used this word to describe the type of liberalism that emerged after World War II, where states combined free trade with social welfare. Karl Polanyi first used this to describe the dependence of economic markets on social systems.
The most significant international institution created after World War II was this successor to the League of Nations. This organization is based in New York City and has a Security Council.

bonuses.leadin: This artist’s paintings are characterized by thin vertical lines called “zips.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this abstract expressionist painter of Black Fire I and Who’s Afraid of Red, Yellow, and Blue? His massive Vir Heroicus Sublimis hangs in the Museum of Modern Art.

A multiple of Newman’s sculpture Broken Obelisk stands in front of a chapel dedicated to this other abstract expressionist. This color field painter created the Seagram Murals for the Four Seasons Hotel.
This other color field artist used clean, crisp lines like Newman, but his work is characterized by smooth curves and large round shapes. He painted Red Curve and the black-and-white Atlantic.

bonuses.leadin: One of this author’s characters marries the rich Cruchot des Bonfons instead of her lover Charles on the condition that he pays off her debts and she doesn’t have to sleep with him. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French author of Cousin Bette and Eugenie Grandet, which are both works in his cycle The Human Comedy.
In this Balzac novella, the title character falls in love with the opera singer La Zambinella, only to discover that she is actually a castrato. Roland Barthes analyzed this story in his S/Z.
Sarrasine has this occupation, for which he got in trouble as a child for practicing on Good Friday. This is also the profession of Arnold Rubek in Ibsen’s When We Dead Awaken.

bonuses.leadin: An invocation of this amendment was rejected in court in 2013 after police officers seized a Nevada family’s home to observe a neighbor’s domestic violence call. For 10 points each:
answers: Third Amendment to the United States Constitution [or Amendment III]
posse comitatus [or The Posse Comitatus Act]
parts: Name this rarely litigated amendment that was used in the case Engblom v. Carey, in which striking prison guards were replaced in their housing by National Guardsmen. This amendment forbids quartering of soldiers.

Judges can issue warrants for these actions, in which officers enter a property without announcing their presence. In a notorious instance of one of these actions, a Georgia baby was burned by a flash-bang grenade.

This Latin phrase refers to the power of a sheriff to summon armed citizens for law enforcement purposes. Its the namesake of an act signed by Hayes forbidding the use of the military as domestic police.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about the cosmogony of a certain ancient religion, for 10 points each:
parts: The initial golden age king, Yima, was overthrown by this dragon demon, a cognate of the Hindu Vritra. This three-headed serpent was subsequently overthrown by the hero Raetone.

At the end of time, Azi Dahaka will appear as the subordinate of this embodiment of Druj, but both will be defeated. According to Zurvanism, this figure proved that he was evil by choice when he created the peacock.

Ahriman is locked in a long-running with Ahura Mazda, the supreme deity of this religion. Important texts in this religion include a collection of hymns called the Gathas, which is part of the Avestas.

bonuses.leadin: Bacteria in these ecosystems use hydrogen sulfide as an energy source in chemosynthesis. For 10 points each:
answers: hydrothermal vent [or black smokers or white smokers]
parts: Name these deep-sea environments where giant tube worms live. They’re fissures in the ocean floor where heated water shoots out.
Based on the ecology of hydrothermal vents, Gunter Wächtershäuser posited this theory of the origin of life, which states that the first organism fixed carbon using transition metal centers.
The “cutthroat” type of these organisms are found in hydrothermal vents. These fish of the order Anguilliformes have transparent larvae called leptocephali.

bonuses.leadin: This man provided the Lewis and Clark Expedition with mercury-containing “bilious pills” meant to prevent the transmission of syphilis. For 10 points each:
answers: bloodletting [or bleeding; or phlebotomy; or leeches; accept descriptive answers that imply removing the patient’s blood]
parts: Name this Founding Father, a physician who organized the government response to the 1793 Philadelphia Yellow Fever epidemic. His son, Richard, negotiated an 1818 treaty that demilitarized the Great Lakes.
Dr. Rush may have accidentally hastened Benjamin Franklin’s death by subjecting him to this medical procedure. George Washington also died shortly after undergoing this procedure.
During the 1793 Yellow Fever outbreak, Rush enlisted this cofounder of the Free African Society to recruit African-American nurses. He founded the African Methodist Episcopal Church in 1794.

bonuses.leadin: A character created by this author compares Rafael Trujillo to Sauron. For 10 points each:
answers: This is How You Lose Her
parts: Name this Dominican-American author who wrote about a sci-fi nerd who is killed after falling in love with Ybon in The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao.

This narrator of The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, Oscar’s roommate, also narrates many of the short stories in the collection Drown. He regrets telling a girl he cheated on “Baby, this is part of my novel” in “Alma.”

Yunior’s brother Rafa gets cancer and marries the title undocumented girl in this collection’s story “The Pura Principle.” Yunior’s relationships are described in this collection's last story, “The Cheater’s Guide to Love.”

bonuses.leadin: One system for classifying these entities contains seven subgroups and was developed by Glenn Trewartha. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these systems, the long-term weather patterns of a region. Examples of these include tropical and subarctic.

The Trewartha climate classification system is a modification of this other system. It uses three letters to designate a climate - one for the major climate group, another for seasonal precipitation, and a third for temperature.

In the Köppen classification, the prefix D is used to designate this type of climate. These climates typically display large seasonal temperature variations, and the mean temperature in the coldest month must be below -3 ºC.

bonuses.leadin: This man’s daughter gets rid of five suitors by asking them to do things like finding a jewel in a swallow’s nest, or bringing her a robe made of fire rats. For 10 points each:
answers: bamboo cutter [or Taketori no Okina; accept anything indicating that we're talking about the old man who chops bamboo for a living from Japanese mythology; prompt on “old man”]
parts: Name this old man from Japanese folklore, who is childless until he finds a gem which grows into the moon princess Kaguya-hime.
One Japanese myth describes a rabbit pounding rice cake in this place. The brother of Amaterasu and Susano’o, Tsukuyomi, is the kami of this place.
One folktale deals with an arrogant prince who boasts that he will take a jewel from one of these creatures but gets seasick. The Shinto god of the sea, Ryujin, is one of these creatures.

bonuses.leadin: Robert Nozick analyzes this non-epistemological phenomenon in the context of normative and non-normative baselines. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phenomenon which Nozick argues is only present when a credible threat changes someone’s behavior by significantly worsening the outcome of their intended action.
Alan Wertheimer distinguishes this situation from coercion due to its capacity to be mutually advantageous. John Roehmer defines this situation as a kind of capitalist social parasitism.

Theorists like Stuart White have argued that this kind of state policy in which all citizens are given a cash transfer is actually exploitative, since this policy would allow people to enjoy gains with no contribution.

bonuses.leadin: Name these saints associated with the French monarchy. For 10 points each:
answers: Louis [or St. Louis; Louis IX of France]
parts: Unsurprisingly, the patron saint of the French monarchy is a monarch of this name who led the Seventh Crusade and died on the Eighth. There were 18 French monarchs of this name.

This third-century Martyr is the patron saint of France and supposedly walked several miles carrying his severed head. Abbot Suger helped build his namesake cathedral north of Paris, which housed the Oriflamme.

This sixth-century Bishop of Rheims established bishoprics at Tournai, Cambrai, and Laon, but is most famous for baptizing Clovis I and a number of his followers, supposedly with a holy oil brought by a dove from heaven.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about electricity, for 10 points each.
parts: These materials have a large band gap, so they do not allow electricity to flow. They are often contrasted with conductors.
For an insulator, this is the voltage that causes them to become partially conductive. For gases, this can be determined using Paschen’s law.
This other type of material is predicted to be a conductor by band theory, but actually isn’t. They have antiferromagnetic ordering and their Hall coefficient changes sign at n = 0 and n = 2.

bonuses.leadin: Alice Mellings plays house mother to an “England-based entity” of the IRA in this author’s satire The Good Terrorist. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, who chronicled the life of Martha Quest in Zimbabwe in her Children of Violence series. She wrote about Mary Turner’s racism toward and murder by her servant Moses in The Grass is Singing.
In this Lessing novel, the writer Anna Wulf divides her life into subjects recorded in black, red, yellow, and blue diaries; it is framed by her novel Free Women.
This other Zimbabwean author wrote about the studious Tambu, who is able to go to missionary school after the death of her brother, in Nervous Conditions and The Book of Not.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about TV shows on ABC. For 10 points each:
parts: This show starring Jeff Garlin and Wendi McLendon-Covey follows the titular family living outside Philadelphia during the 1980s. It is based on videotapes the creator made of his family during his childhood.
On Designated Survivor, this actor plays Tom Kirkman, the Housing and Urban Development Secretary forced into the Presidency after a bombing during the State of the Union address.
In 2017, ABC revived this 1970s NBC talent show with Mike Myers hosting under the alter ego Tommy Maitland. On this show, celebrity judges can sound the titular instrument to end a performance early.

bonuses.leadin: An Jung-Geun assassinated this politician for engineering the deposition of Emperor Gojong. For 10 points each:
answers: Korea [or North Korea; South Korea; Kankoku; Chosun; Hanguk]
parts: Name this politician who founded the Seiyukai party to oppose the Kenseito party. This genro was greatly influenced by the Prussian Constitution and was his country’s first Prime Minister.
Ito was assassinated for his role in obtaining Japanese influence over this region. After World War II, this region was split into two countries, with the northern ruled by Kim Il-Sung.

Ito was Prime Minister under the Meiji emperor, who was succeeded as emperor by this father of Hirohito. This emperor only had limited power due to mental issues, and he ruled during the Great Kanto Earthquake.

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s fourth symphony titled “The Gardens” was commissioned by Michigan State University. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this composer who became the first female to win the Pulitzer Prize for music with her Three Movements for an Orchestra. In 1995, this woman was appointed as the first composer-in-residence of Carnegie Hall.

This other Pulitzer prize winner and current Carnegie Hall’s composer-in-residence celebrated his eightieth birthday with the world premiere of his piece Pulse. He is best known for composing Different Trains and Music for 18 Musicians.

When John Adams won his first Pulitzer, he received it for composing this piece in memory of victims of 9/11. This piece notably quotes from Ives’s Unanswered Question and features a tape recording of the list of victims.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, a pedophile is constantly referred to as the “Lecherous Lecturer,” but everyone thinks he is harmless and the nickname is just for alliteration. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel narrated by Fanny Logan about her friend Polly, who is bored by love affairs but marries her uncle Boy Douglas, who subsequently runs off with the Canadian Cedric Hampton.

Love in a Cold Climate is by Nancy, one of this set of six aristocratic sisters. They were known for extreme political views, from the Hitler-loving Unity to the Communist Jessica, who wrote The American Way of Death.

In Love in a Cold Climate, Polly returns to England from this colony. Joseph Sedley works in the civil service in this colony in Vanity Fair, and E. M. Forster wrote about Dr. Aziz and Adela Quested in A Passage to [this place].

bonuses.leadin: This technique has been used for clinical detection of low-concentration metabolites such as catecholamines. For 10 points each:
answers: HPLC [or High-Pressure Liquid Chromatography; or High Performance Liquid Chromatography]
parts: Name this type of chromatography that forces the sample through a column at up to 600 atm. The elution of sample can be done in isocratic or gradient modes depending on the composition of the solvent.
Unlike normal phase liquid chromatography, reversed-phase HPLC has nonpolar stationary phase and polar solvent in this phase that moves through the column.
This organic solvent or methanol is typically used as the polar solvent for reversed-phased HPLC due to its low reactivity and ability to dissolve nonpolar or ionic samples. Its formula is CH3CN.

bonuses.leadin: This ballet’s choreographer named it after a line from Hart Crane’s poem “The Dance.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ballet in which newlyweds build a farmhouse but are interrupted by a revivalist and her followers, with set design by Isamu Noguchi.
This American choreographer of Appalachian Spring emphasized “contraction and release” in her style of modern dance.

This friend of Martha Graham staged Aaron Copland’s ballet Rodeo as a romance between the “Cowgirl” and the “Roper.” She primarily choreographed musicals such as Oklahoma! and Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.
